ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.2_0: At that time the monks of Āḷavī were building huts by means of begging. The huts were intended for themselves, did not have a sponsoring owner, and were inappropriate in size.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.3_0: And that because they were never completed,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.4_0: They kept on begging and asking,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.5_0: “Give a man, give a servant, give an ox, give a cart, give a machete, give a hatchet, give an ax, give a spade, give a chisel, give a creeper, give bamboo, give reed, give grass, give clay.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.6_0: and people felt oppressed to the point where they now avoid monks?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.7_0: They even ran away when they saw cows, thinking they were monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.8_0: Just then Venerable Mahākassapa, after completing the rainy-season residence at Rājagaha, set out for Āḷavī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.9_0: When he eventually arrived in Āḷavī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.10_0: he stayed at the Aggāḷava Shrine.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.11_0: Then Venerable Mahākassapa robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āḷavī for alms.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.12_0: When people saw him they became fearful and alarmed, and they ran away, took a different path, turned away, and closed their doors.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.13_0: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.14_0: “Āḷavī used to have plenty of food, and it wasn’t difficult to get by on almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.15_0: But now Āḷavī is short of almsfood, and it’s not easy to get by on alms.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.17_0: And they told him what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.1_0: Soon afterwards, after staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, the Buddha too set out wandering toward Āḷavī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.3_0: he too stayed at the Aggāḷava Shrine.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.4_0: Then Venerable Mahākassapa approached the Fortunate One,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.5_0: and told the Buddha what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.6_0: The Buddha then had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks of Āḷavī:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.7_0: “Is it true, monks, that you’re building huts through begging, huts intended for yourself, without a sponsoring owner, and inappropriate in size?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.8_0: And that because they were never completed,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.9_0: you kept on asking and begging
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.11_0: and people felt oppressed to the point where they now avoid monks?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.14_0: “... Foolish men, how can you build huts through begging?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.15_0: And that because they were never completed,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.16_0: you kept on asking and begging
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.17_0: “Give a man, give a male person, give grass, clay.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.18_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.19_0: after criticizing them, he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.1_0: “Once upon a time, monks, two sages who were brothers lived near the river Ganges.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.2_0: Soon the dragon king again emerged from the Ganges and approached the younger sage.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.2_1: and after approaching he stood on a plough with a driver’s head, (thinking): “The Seventhous side”,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.3_0: Because he did not get pale, the young sage became thinner, haggard, and pale, his veins protruding all over his limbs.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.4_0: The older sage saw him like this
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.5_0: and asked him what was the matter.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.6_0: ‘You’re thin, haggard, and pale, your veins protruding all over your limbs.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.7_0: ‘It’s when the dragon king emerges from the Ganges and approached the younger shop.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.7_1: and after approaching, they stood leaning on a large couch with a stone.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.8_0: And I’m thin, haggard, and pale, my veins protruding all over my limbs.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.9_0: The elder sage said, ‘Would you like that dragon not to return?’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.11_0: ‘Well then, did you see anything belonging to that dragon?’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.12_0: ‘I see gems, sirs, I shall be cut off.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.13_0: ‘Well then, sirs, ask the dragon for his gem,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.16_0: Soon the dragon king again emerged from the Ganges and approached the younger sage.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.16_1: and after approaching he stood on one side.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.17_0: And the sage said to him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.21_0: ‘The monk is asking for the gem,’ and he quickly left.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.22_0: Once more the dragon king emerged from the Ganges and approached the younger sage.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.29_0: Yet again the dragon king emerged from the Ganges.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.30_0: The younger sage saw him emerging
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.34_0: The dragon king then spoke these verses to the sage:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.35_0: ‘My food and drink are abundant and sublime,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.36_0: And they appear because of this gem.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.37_0: I will not give to you, you beg too much,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.38_0: Nor will I return to your hermitage.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.39_0: Like a youth with a clean sword in his hand,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.40_0: You frighten me, asking for this gem.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.41_0: I will not give to you, you beg too much,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.42_0: Nor will I return to your hermitage.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.44_0: ‘The monk is asking for the gem; he wants the gem,’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.46_0: Because he did not get to see that beautiful dragon, the young sage became even thinner, more haggard and pale, his veins protruding even more.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.47_0: The older sage saw him like this
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.48_0: and asked him what was the matter.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.49_0: ‘Sir, you’re thin, haggard, and pale, your veins protruding all over your limbs.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.51_0: The older sage then spoke to him in verse:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.52_0: ‘One shouldn’t beg from those one wishes to be dear to;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.54_0: When the brahmin asked the dragon for his gem,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.55_0: It left and was never to be seen again.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.56_0: For even though they disagreeable animals, you’ll begging for them.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.1_0: “At one time, monks, a certain monk lived in a forest grove on the slopes of the Himalayas.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.2_0: Not far from that grove was a large, low-lying marsh.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.3_0: A great flock of birds fed in the marsh during the day and entered the grove to roost at night.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.4_0: Then that mendicant went to a bundle of flock of birds.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.4_1: and after approaching and worshipping me, he sat down on one side.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.6_0: ‘I hope you are keeping well, monk, I hope you’re comfortable;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.7_0: I hope you’re not tired from traveling.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.8_0: And where have you come from?’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.11_0: On the slopes of the Himalayas there’s a great forest grove
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.12_0: and close by a large low-lying marsh.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.13_0: A large flock of birds feeds in that low-lying marsh during the day and comes at night to roost in that forest grove.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.14_0: That’s where I’ve come from, Sir,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.15_0: and I left because I was disturbed by the noise of that flock of birds.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.16_0: ‘Would you like that flock of birds not to return?’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.17_0: ‘Sir, I would like to have no going to the birds of flocks.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.18_0: ‘Well then, go back to that forest grove. In the first part of the night, call out three times,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.20_0: From whoever roosts in this forest grove, I want a feather.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.21_0: Each one of you must give me a feather.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.23_0: and third part of the night do the same thing.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.25_0: From whoever roosts in this forest grove, I want a feather.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.26_0: Each one of you must give me a feather.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.27_0: The monk returned to that forest grove and did as instructed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.29_0: From whoever roosts in this forest grove, I want a feather.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.30_0: Each one of you must give me a feather.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.32_0: and third part of the night do the same thing.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.34_0: From whoever roosts in this forest grove, I want a feather.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.35_0: Each one of you must give me a feather.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.37_0: ‘The monk is asking for a feather; he wants a feather,’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.40_0: For even though they disagreeable animals, you’ll begging for them.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.1_0: Once upon a time, Raṭṭhapāla’s father addressed him in verse:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.5_0: So why don’t you beg from me?’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.8_0: That’s why I do not beg from you;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.9_0: Please don’t hate me for this.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.10_0: If Raṭṭhapāla, who came from a good family, could speak like this to his own father,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.11_0: how much more, then, can people do so to each other.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.1_0: It’s hard, monks, for householders to acquire and protect their possessions.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.2_0: And still, foolish men, you kept on asking and begging
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.4_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.5_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.6.1_0: ‘When a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.6.1_1: It is to be no more than twelve standard handspans long:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.7_0: He must get monks to approve a site where no harm will be done and which has a space on all sides.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.8_0: If a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut on a site where harm will be done and which lacks a space on all sides, or he does not get monks to approve the site, or he exceeds the right size, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.2_0: having himself begged for a man, a servant, an ox, a cart, a machete, a hatchet, an ax, a spade, a chisel, a creeper, bamboo, reed, grass, clay.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.4_0: plastered inside or plastered outside or plastered both inside and outside.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.6_0: is making or is having made.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.8_0: there is no other owner, either a woman or a man, either a lay person or one gone forth.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.11_0: he should be made the right size.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.12_0: It is to be no more than twelve standard handspans long:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.1_0: He must get monks to approve a site:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.2_0: The monk who wishes to build a hut should clear a site. He should then approach the Sangha, put his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the senior monks, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.3_0: ‘Venerables, I wish, by means of begging, to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for myself.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.4_0: I request the Sangha to inspect the site for the hut.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.5_0: And they should ask a second
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.7_0: If the whole Sangha is able to inspect the site, they should all go.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.8_0: If the whole Sangha is not able to inspect the site, then those monks there who are competent and capable—who know where harm will be done and where no harm will be done, and who know what is meant by a space on all sides and a lack of space on all sides—should be asked and then appointed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.9_0: “And, monks, they should be appointed like this.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.10_0: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.11_0: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.12_0: Monk so-and-so, by means of begging, wishes to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.13_0: He is requesting the Sangha to inspect the site for the hut.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.14_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should appoint monk so-and-so and monk so-and-so to inspect the site.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.16_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.17_0: Monk so-and-so, by means of begging, wishes to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.18_0: He is requesting the Sangha to inspect the site for the hut.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.19_0: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so and monk so-and-so to inspect the site for a hut for monk so-and-so.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.20_0: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so and monk so-and-so to inspect the site for the hut should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.21_0: Any monk who doesn’t agree should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.22_0: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so and monk so-and-so to inspect the site for a hut for monk so-and-so.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.23_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.25_0: The appointed monks should go and inspect the site for the hut to find out if any harm will be done and if it has a space on all sides.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.26_0: If harm will be done and it lacks a space on all sides, they should say, ‘Don’t build here.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.27_0: If no harm will be done and it has a space on all sides, they should inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.28_0: ‘No harm will be done and it has a space on all sides.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.29_0: The monk who wishes to build the hut should then approach the Sangha, put his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the senior monks, squat on his heels with his palms together, and say:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.30_0: ‘Venerables, I wish, by means of begging, to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for myself.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.31_0: I request the Sangha to approve the site for the hut.”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.37_0: He is requesting the Sangha to approve the site for the hut.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.2_0: it is the abode of ants, termites, rats, snakes, scorpions, centipedes, elephants, horses, lions, tigers, leopards, bears, or hyenas, or any other animals;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.3_0: or it is bordering on a field of grain, a field of vegetables, a slaughtering-place, a place of execution, a charnel ground, a park, a king’s property, an elephant-stable, a horse-stable, a prison, a bar, a slaughterhouse, a vehicle road, a crossroads, a public meeting hall, or a cul-de-sac—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.4_0: this is called “where harm will be done”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.5_0: Which lacks a space on all sides:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.6_0: it is not possible to go around it with a yoked cart, or to go all the way around it with a ladder—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.6_1: this is called “which lacks a space on all sides”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.7_0: where no harm will be done:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.8_0: it is not the abode of ants, termites, rats, snakes, scorpions, centipedes ... it is not bordering on ... a cul-de-sac—this is no harm.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.8_1: it is not bordering on ... a cul-de-sac—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.8_2: this is called “where no harm will be done”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.9_0: Which lacks a space on all sides:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.10_0: it is possible to go around it with a yoked cart, or to go all the way around it with a ladder—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.10_1: this is called “which has a space on all sides”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.2_0: having himself begged for a man, a servant ... clay.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.4_0: plastered inside or plastered outside or plastered both inside and outside.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.6_0: building it himself or having someone else build it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.7_0: Or he does not get monks to approve the site, or he exceeds the right size:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.8_0: if the site for the hut has not been approved through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements, or he builds a hut or has one built which exceeds the allowable length or breadth even by the width of a hair, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.9_0: When one piece is left to complete the hut, he commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.10_0: When the last piece is finished, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.11_0: He commits an offense entailing suspension:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.12_0: ... Therefore, too, it is called “an offense entailing suspension”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.1_0: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and two offenses of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.2_0: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.3_0: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct.
